MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
scenario: No violation: the cls pointer is converted to DIR * and passed to readdir(), which modifies the DIR stream state, and buf is written to via snprintf. Therefore neither pointer can be const-qualified here. (A violation would occur if a pointer parameter were only read and never used to modify the pointee — e.g. a purely input-only generic pointer declared as void * instead of const void *.)
